HEADS OF ACTIVITIES
SPEAK TO ASSEMBLY
Eight students who head the various activities of the Johns Hopkins
University spoke on the work of their
respective organizations at the weekly assembly held yesterday in Latrobe
Hall. Before the talks Clifford Gilbert, head cheer leader, led the gathering in several Hopkins yells. He
requested aspirants for positions of
cheer leaders and added that a major
"H" will be given the head cheer leader after three years of active service.
Robert Abrams, chairman of the
Student Activities Committee, explained the working of this new addition to the campus. He said that its
main functions were to set as an advisory board to Dean Edward W.

De Hoff Speaks
John De Hoff, editor-in-chief of the
yearbook, The Hullabaloo, called for
candidates to the editorial, photography and art staffs, in addition to outlining the kind of work in an annual.
The president of the Musical Club
and the Y. M. C. A., Carson Frailey,
introduced both groups to the assembly. The Supper Club, Speakers' Bureau, and the "Y" News were among

In conjunction with the present
plan for improving athletic conditions at Johns Hopkins, the Board of
Trustees has announced a donation
of $10,000, to be used primarily for
a heating plant in the lockers.
The plant will be situated underneath the new annex to the gymnasium and will provide for a drying
room which will greatly aid In taking care of the added necessary
supplies.
In addition to the heating plant,
225 extra lockers will be built to
accomodate students engaging in intramural and interfraternity sports.
/t is also planned to build in more
showers and generally modernize the
locker-rooms.
Gym To Open
This marks a new milestone in
Hopkins athletic history, as there is
no heating plant in the old lockers,
and scarcely enough space for the
varsity teams. The new system is expected to result in greater participation in sports by the general student body, and indirectly in an imrovement in the quality of varsity
teams.
Dr. Shaffer stated that the gymnasium would be open for the students in about 10 days. While little
new equipment has been bought
there is some from the old Hopkins
This ingymnasium can be used.
cludes punching bags, parallel bars,
boxing gloves, and various exercising machines that will be stationed
around the walls. The creating of an
indoor tennis court has been considered, but this is qs yet indefinite.

Hopkins Asks For $500,000
In First Appeal In 8 Years;
Will Reach Entire Country

To Aid Free Clinics
Entire Amount To Be Devoted To Continuing Free
Service For Local Poor
In order to continue its care of
thousands of needy Baltimoreans the
Johns Hopkins Hospital will conduct
a public campaign for $500,000 this
winter. This is the hospital's first
public appeal for funds since 1926.
According to Henry D. Harlan,
former Chief Judge of the Supreme
Bench of Baltimore City and the present chairman of the hospital's board
of trustees, the hospital will be forced
to drastically curtail or perhaps abandon its free bed and clinical work
unless sufficient funds are soon forthcoming.
Several million dollars were raised
eight years ago, the time of the last
public campaign for money, which
was divided bewteen the hospital and
the University. Since then the funds
have steadily decreased. Only last
year the free work amounted to $503.000, exceeding the available income by
about $45,000. Mr. Harlan pointed
out that last year was not the first
that such a deficit had been incurred
by the hospital. Also that up to this
time the deficits had been met by a
surplus accumulated by the hospital
through the sale of securities and
property at a profit.
Nation-Wide Appeal Planned
"Twenty-five per cent, of all the
free work done by the hospitals
throughout the city of Baltimore was
done by the Johns Hopkins Hospital,"
said Mr. Harlan. "Thus were the institution to abandon its work it would
cost the city at least $500,000 to provide for the patients."
The appeal is being made primarily
to Baltimoreans, although efforts will
be made to interest friends of the
great institution elsewhere.
It was also pointed out that the
actual pay of all hospital employes,
from the director down to the scrubwomen, now averages less than $15
a week. In addition, Mr. Harlan reported that 195 of the 950 available
beds in .the hospital must be kept
empty because of lack of funds to
maintain them.
W. Frank Roberts has been appointed executive chairman of the
campaign committee. He will be assisted by a planning committee composed of the following:
George Weems Williams, John S.
Gibbs, Jr. John Sawyer Wilson, Jr.,
J. Edward Johnston and Dr. Winthrop
H. Smith, hospital director.

Six-Man Backfield
Sleepy Jim Crowley, of Fordham,
has figured out an improvement on
the five-man backfield invented by Bo
McMillen, of Indiana. In the "Crowley Flexible Shift," to be tried against
Boston College today, both guards
drop behind the scrimmage line, putting six men in the backfield until
time for the two to return to the line
a s cond before the ball is passed.

Likes Team's Spirit
For the past four years he has
taken part in University athletics,
having been a member of the varsity
football team for the entire period.
He has received the honor of being
chosen on several mythical All-Maryland football teams and this year is
captain of the Blue Jay eleven.

Football found in Dotterweich an
excellent punter, but handicapped by
injuries, Frank spent his time on the
sidelines. In this connection he was
penned "Rocking Chair Frank",
choosing to pass the hours away on
the sidelines at training camp in a
rocking chair, and dozing to the
rythmical creak of the chair.

McClean thinks that the squad of
students now out for the football
team are an extremely school-spirited
bunch, particularly, because they are
willing to work so hard in spite of
the present status of intercollegiate
football. In regard to the probable
success or failure of the team in
games won and lost Billy does not
care to make a statement for he feels
that the Jays are still an unknown
quantity.

Dotterweich is a member of the NaSoccer Referee Association, and has
been most active in this field, working the last state championship. He
spent two years as a leader in the
Playground Athletic League and is
now there as a full time instructor in
the newly formed Athletic Department. Dotterweich received his degree in Engineering at the Hopkins
in '28.

Outside Competition Plentiful
Plans for intercollegiate competition are now well under way. The
teams will take several trips in the
city as well as in the vicinity of Baltimore. Also an inter-class league is
in the process of formation, so that
every team will have competition
even though it may not go on one of
the trips.

Columbia Changes 'Em
For the second time in recent years
Lou Little has reached into his Columbia backfield squad for a reserve
center. Last year it was Newt Wilder, originally a fullback, who got the
job. Now, it is Frank Chippendale,
another fullback, who is being
groomed as a reserve for Al Ciampsa.

In conjunction with the present
plan for improving athletic conditions at Johns Hopkins, the Board of
Trustees has announced a donation
of $10,000, to be used primarily for
a heating plant in the lockers.
The plant will be situated underneath the new annex to the gymnasium and will provide for a drying
room which will greatly aid In taking care of the added necessary
supplies.
In addition to the heating plant,
225 extra lockers will be built to
accomodate students engaging in intramural and interfraternity sports.
/t is also planned to build in more
showers and generally modernize the
locker-rooms.
Gym To Open
This marks a new milestone in
Hopkins athletic history, as there is
no heating plant in the old lockers,
and scarcely enough space for the
varsity teams. The new system is expected to result in greater participation in sports by the general student body, and indirectly in an imrovement in the quality of varsity
teams.
Dr. Shaffer stated that the gymnasium would be open for the students in about 10 days. While little
new equipment has been bought
there is some from the old Hopkins
This ingymnasium can be used.
cludes punching bags, parallel bars,
boxing gloves, and various exercising machines that will be stationed
around the walls. The creating of an
indoor tennis court has been considered, but this is qs yet indefinite.

Hopkins Asks For $500,000
In First Appeal In 8 Years;
Will Reach Entire Country

To Aid Free Clinics
Entire Amount To Be Devoted To Continuing Free
Service For Local Poor
In order to continue its care of
thousands of needy Baltimoreans the
Johns Hopkins Hospital will conduct
a public campaign for $500,000 this
winter. This is the hospital's first
public appeal for funds since 1926.
According to Henry D. Harlan,
former Chief Judge of the Supreme
Bench of Baltimore City and the present chairman of the hospital's board
of trustees, the hospital will be forced
to drastically curtail or perhaps abandon its free bed and clinical work
unless sufficient funds are soon forthcoming.
Several million dollars were raised
eight years ago, the time of the last
public campaign for money, which
was divided bewteen the hospital and
the University. Since then the funds
have steadily decreased. Only last
year the free work amounted to $503.000, exceeding the available income by
about $45,000. Mr. Harlan pointed
out that last year was not the first
that such a deficit had been incurred
by the hospital. Also that up to this
time the deficits had been met by a
surplus accumulated by the hospital
through the sale of securities and
property at a profit.
Nation-Wide Appeal Planned
"Twenty-five per cent, of all the
free work done by the hospitals
throughout the city of Baltimore was
done by the Johns Hopkins Hospital,"
said Mr. Harlan. "Thus were the institution to abandon its work it would
cost the city at least $500,000 to provide for the patients."
The appeal is being made primarily
to Baltimoreans, although efforts will
be made to interest friends of the
great institution elsewhere.
It was also pointed out that the
actual pay of all hospital employes,
from the director down to the scrubwomen, now averages less than $15
a week. In addition, Mr. Harlan reported that 195 of the 950 available
beds in .the hospital must be kept
empty because of lack of funds to
maintain them.
W. Frank Roberts has been appointed executive chairman of the
campaign committee. He will be assisted by a planning committee composed of the following:
George Weems Williams, John S.
Gibbs, Jr. John Sawyer Wilson, Jr.,
J. Edward Johnston and Dr. Winthrop
H. Smith, hospital director.

Six-Man Backfield
Sleepy Jim Crowley, of Fordham,
has figured out an improvement on
the five-man backfield invented by Bo
McMillen, of Indiana. In the "Crowley Flexible Shift," to be tried against
Boston College today, both guards
drop behind the scrimmage line, putting six men in the backfield until
time for the two to return to the line
a s cond before the ball is passed.

Likes Team's Spirit
For the past four years he has
taken part in University athletics,
having been a member of the varsity
football team for the entire period.
He has received the honor of being
chosen on several mythical All-Maryland football teams and this year is
captain of the Blue Jay eleven.

Football found in Dotterweich an
excellent punter, but handicapped by
injuries, Frank spent his time on the
sidelines. In this connection he was
penned "Rocking Chair Frank",
choosing to pass the hours away on
the sidelines at training camp in a
rocking chair, and dozing to the
rythmical creak of the chair.

McClean thinks that the squad of
students now out for the football
team are an extremely school-spirited
bunch, particularly, because they are
willing to work so hard in spite of
the present status of intercollegiate
football. In regard to the probable
success or failure of the team in
games won and lost Billy does not
care to make a statement for he feels
that the Jays are still an unknown
quantity.

Dotterweich is a member of the NaSoccer Referee Association, and has
been most active in this field, working the last state championship. He
spent two years as a leader in the
Playground Athletic League and is
now there as a full time instructor in
the newly formed Athletic Department. Dotterweich received his degree in Engineering at the Hopkins
in '28.

Outside Competition Plentiful
Plans for intercollegiate competition are now well under way. The
teams will take several trips in the
city as well as in the vicinity of Baltimore. Also an inter-class league is
in the process of formation, so that
every team will have competition
even though it may not go on one of
the trips.

Columbia Changes 'Em
For the second time in recent years
Lou Little has reached into his Columbia backfield squad for a reserve
center. Last year it was Newt Wilder, originally a fullback, who got the
job. Now, it is Frank Chippendale,
another fullback, who is being
groomed as a reserve for Al Ciampsa.
